summary: This document appears to be internal email correspondence among corrections staff discussing the management of Jeffrey Epstein while he was on suicide watch (SW) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The staff debate protocols, such as allowing Epstein to attend a legal visit in regular clothes while on suicide watch, and reference a mark or scar on Epstein's neck. The discussion compares practices at MCC with other detention centers like one in Chicago.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate being discussed; was on suicide watch at MCC, had a mark/scar on his neck, and was allowed a legal visit in regular clothes.

events.title: Epstein on Suicide Watch with Neck Injury
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was on suicide watch at MCC and had a mark or huge scar on his neck, with ambiguity surrounding how it occurred.

events.title: Internal Staff Debate on Epstein's Suicide Watch Protocols
events.description: Corrections staff exchanged emails debating whether Epstein should have been allowed a legal visit in regular clothes while on suicide watch, citing a chief at another detention center who questioned the practice.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in July 2019.
Epstein had a 'huge scar' or mark on his neck, with ambiguity surrounding the incident that caused it.
Staff allowed Epstein to attend a legal visit while on suicide watch and in regular clothes, which was questioned by a chief at another detention center.
Internal correspondence reveals debate among corrections staff about the overuse of suicide watch and differing protocols between MCC and other facilities like one in Chicago.
The document is dated July 24, 2019, and is part of the EFTA document set related to the Epstein case.
